tn.text: The book of Judges continues the story about Joshua and is also the beginning of a new part of the story.
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.

tn.ref: will attack the Canaanites for us
tn.text: The word "us" refers to the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])

Here "Judah" represents the the men of the tribe of Judah. Yahweh is commanding these men to attack first. AT: "The men of Judah must attack first" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]])
"Look" or "Indeed." This adds emphasis to what follows.
This refers to the land where the Canaanites lived. AT: "the land of the Canaanites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])
"their fellow Israelites" or "their relatives"

The people of the tribes of Judah and Simeon were camped with the rest of the Israelite people in the valley of the Jordan River. The land given to Judah was in the hills above the valley. Some languages do not usually indicate whether people were going up or down. AT: "Come with us" or "Go with us"

tn.ref: that was assigned to us ... that was assigned to you
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "that Yahweh assigned to us ... that Yahweh assigned to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])

tn.ref: We will likewise go with you
tn.text: "We will also go with you" or "In the same way, we will go with you"
It is implied that the men of Simeon attacked with the men of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"They killed about 10,000" or "They killed a large number" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"soldiers of the Canaanites and Perizzites" or "enemies"
This is an area in the mountains of Canaan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This man was the leader of the army of the Canaanites and the Perizzites. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "him" actually refers to Adoni Bezek and his army. AT: "they fought against him and his army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"chased him"
"70 kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: who had their thumbs and their big toes cut off
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "whose thumbs and big toes I told my men to cut off" or "whose thumbs and big toes we cut off" (See" [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: gathered their food from under my table
tn.text: "ate scraps of food from under my table." Forcing these kings to eat scraps of food represents all the ways that Adoni Bezek humiliated these kings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the city of Jerusalem and took it
tn.text: Here "city" represents the people. AT: "the people who lived in Jerusalem and defeated them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "it" refers to the city which represents the people of the city. AT: "They attacked the people of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: with the edge of the sword
tn.text: "with the point of the sword." Here "sword" represents the swords and other weapons that the soldiers used in battle. AT: "with their swords" or "with their weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the men of Judah went down to fight
tn.text: It was common to use the word "down" when it refers to traveling from Jerusalem. AT: "the men of Judah went to fight"
"in the southern Judean wilderness" (UDB)
hills at the base of a mountain or mountain range

tn.ref: the name of Hebron was previously Kiriath Arba
tn.text: This is background information. Some people who first read this book had probably heard of Kiriath Arba but did not know that it was the same as the city that they called Hebron. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

These are the names of three Canaanite leaders of Hebron. Each leader represents his army. AT: "Sheshai, Ahiman, Talmai, and their armies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the name of Debir was previously Kiriath Sepher
tn.text: The author probably wrote this because his readers knew the city as Debir. But at the time Israel attacked it, it was called Kiriath Sepher. AT: "which used to be called Kiriath Sepher" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background|Background Information]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"in times past" or "at an earlier time"

tn.ref: Whoever attacks Kiriath Sepher and takes it
tn.text: Here "Kiriath Sepher" represents the people. AT: "Whoever attacks and defeats the people of Kiriath Sepher and takes their city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]])
This is the name of Caleb's daughter. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"Achsah urged Othniel"

tn.ref: give her a field ... Since you have given me the land
tn.text: This implies that Caleb did give her the field when she asked him for it in verse 14. In verse 15, she is now asking for springs of water in addition to that field. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Do a favor for me" or "Do this for me"

tn.ref: Since you have given me the land of the Negev
tn.text: Caleb gave Achsah in marriage to Othniel, so she lived with Othniel in the city that he had captured in the Negev. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "Since you have given me in marriage to live in the Negev" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
in-law** - "of the father of Moses' wife"
in-law the Kenite went up** - "father-in-law, who was one of the Ken people, went up"

tn.ref: went up from the City of Palms ... into the wilderness
tn.text: "left the City of Palms ... and went into the wilderness"
This is another name for the city of Jericho. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is the name of a city in Canaan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the men of Simeon their brothers
tn.text: Here "brothers" means relatives who were in another tribe of Israel.
This is the name of a city in Canaan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: The name of the city was called Hormah
tn.text: After the Israelites destroyed Zephath, they changed its name to "Hormah." The name "Hormah" means "complete destruction." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Yahweh was with the people of Judah
tn.text: Here "was with" means that Yahweh helped the people of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
a very large area of level, treeless ground

tn.ref: Hebron was given to Caleb (like Moses had said)
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Moses had given Hebron to Caleb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The leaders of the people groups are used to refer to the entire group. AT: "three sons of Anak and their people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the name of a man. Anak and his descendants were famous for being very tall. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"until now." This refers to the time the book of Judges was written.

Here "house" represents descendants. Manasseh and Ephraim were sons of Joseph, and the "house of Joseph" can refer to the descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim. AT: "The descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim" or "The men of the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "Bethel" represents the people who live in Bethel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
to get information secretly

tn.ref: the city that was formerly called Luz
tn.text: This is background information. Some people who first read this book had probably heard of Luz but did not know that it was the same as the city that they called Bethel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
people who get information secretly
Here "city" represents the people. AT: "they attacked the people of the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: with the edge of the sword
tn.text: "with the point of the sword." Here "sword" represents the swords and other weapons that the soldiers used in battle. AT: "with their swords" or "with their weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is an idiom. AT: "escape" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This new town started in the land of the Hittites was named after the town of Luz, near Bethel, that the man had left.

tn.ref: which is its name to this day
tn.text: "which is still its name." Here "to this day" refers to the time when the book of Judges was written.

tn.ref: Beth Shan ... Taanach ... Dor ... Ibleam ... Megiddo
tn.text: These are names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: because the Canaanites were determined to live in that land
tn.text: To "determine" is to firmly decide something. AT: "because the Canaanites firmly decided not to leave that land"
Here "Israel" represents the people. AT: "When the people of Israel became stronger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they forced the Canaanites to serve them with hard labor
tn.text: "they forced the Canaanites to do hard work for them"
Here "Ephraim" represents the men or the soldiers of the tribe of Ephraim. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The name of one of the cities in the Ephraim area. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "Zebulun" represents the men or the soldiers of the tribe of Zebulun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are names of cities in the land of Canaan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "Zebulun" represents the people of the tribe of Zebulun. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"difficult labor"
Here "Asher" represents the men or the soldiers of the tribe of Asher. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Acco ... Sidon ... Ahlab, Achzib, Helbah, Aphik ... Rehob
tn.text: These are names of cities in the land of Canaan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the inhabitants of Beth Shemesh and Beth Anath were forced into hard labor for Naphthali
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people of Naphtali forced the people of Beth Shemesh and Beth Anath to work for them as slaves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: not allowing them to come down
tn.text: "stopping them from coming down"
a very large area of flat land without trees
This is the name of a large hill on which the city of Aijalon was built. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of cities. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: the military might of the house of Joseph conquered them
tn.text: "the tribes of people who descended from Joseph were able to conquer them because of their powerful army"

Here "house" represents descendants. Manasseh and Ephraim were sons of Joseph, and the "house of Joseph" can refer to the descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim. AT: "the descendants of Manasseh and Ephraim" or "the men of the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This was a pass southwest of the Dead Sea. It is also called the "Scorpion Pass." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
